isis.stitle: AIR CONDITIONING COMPRESSOR AND CLUTCH TWO CYLINDER RECIPROCATING TYPE - BEFORE 01/01/1993 (R-12) - REMOVE AND INSTALL - CRANKSHAFT BEARINGS

svcsubproc.title: Remove
svcsubproc.para: Replacement of the front and/or rear crankshaft bearing(s) requires complete disassembly of the compressor. Special care must be taken as many of the critical parts such as pistons, connecting rods, connecting rod bearings, etc. are not available as replacement parts. Normally the front and rear bearings are replaced at the same time since they may be damaged in the disassembly of the unit.

step1.para: Remove the magnetic clutch valve plate assembly and cylinder head. Refer to CLUTCH ASSEMBLY, and VALVE PLATE ASSEMBLY.

Remove the screws securing the crankshaft rear bearing housing to the crankcase. Using two screwdrivers or similar tools, carefully pry the housing out of the crankcase bore ( Figure 23). Pry so that the housing is pulled out parallel to the bearing surface.

figure.caption: Figure 23. Removing Crankshaft Rear Bearing Housing

caution.para: Be careful when using a screwdriver to remove the bearing housing. Do not damage the wall of bore. Damage to the bore can cause oil leaks.

step1.para: Remove the rear bearing housing and O-ring seal ( Figure 24).

figure.caption: Figure 24. Crankshaft Rear Bearing Housing and O-Ring Removed

step1.para: Remove the capscrews and gently pry or tap the base plate to loosen the gasket. Remove the base plate from the crankcase ( Figure 25).

Match mark the connecting rod, connecting rod bearing caps and crankshaft bearing throws to be certain that they are installed in their original positions during reassembly to maintain pre-established wear patterns.
Using a 12-point socket, remove the connecting rod bearing capscrews. Remove the connecting rod bearing caps ( Figure 26).

figure.caption: Figure 26. Connecting Rod Bearing Caps Removed

step1.para: Remove the pistons from the cylinders ( Figure 27).
Remove the crankshaft front bearing from the crankcase.

note.para: The crankshaft front bearing is a ball type bearing and is a shrink fit into a recess in the crankcase.

step1.para: The preferred method of bearing removal is to oven heat the crankcase to 300°F (149°C). The complete crankcase must be heated. Localized heating may crack the crankcase. At the specified temperature, the crankshaft and ball bearing assembly can easily be removed.

warning.para: Insulated gloves or similar protection should be worn to prevent possible burns during handling of the hot crankcase.

step1.para: To remove the front bearing from the crankshaft after heating, place the crankshaft in a vise, keyway end up, gripping the shaft in a non-machined area between the throws. Using two large screwdrivers or similar tools as a pry, force the bearing upward and remove it from the shaft. Pry the rear bearing off the crankshaft if necessary.
If no oven or means of evenly heating the crankcase is available, the bearing and crankshaft may be pressed out of the crankcase.

Support the crankcase in the arbor press ( Figure 28). Press out the crankshaft. If the bearing comes out with the crankshaft, remove the bearing from the crankshaft as described in the Heating Method instructions.
If the bearing remains in the crankcase, support the crankcase in an arbor press and press the bearing out of the crankcase ( Figure 29).

figure.caption: Figure 29. Removing Crankshaft Front Bearing From Crankshaft

step1.para: Press the rear bearing onto the crankshaft by exerting pressure on the inner race of the bearing. Make sure the crankshaft, bearing and the recess in the crankcase are clean and free of burrs.
Install the crankshaft front bearing in the crankcase.

Oven heat the crankcase to 300°F (149°C). Place the crankcase front bearing in the crankcase recess. If necessary, apply force to the bearing outer race to be sure that the bearing is seated in the bottom of the recess.

warning.para: Insulated gloves or similar protection should be worn to prevent possible burns during handling of the hot crankcase.

step1.para: Allow the crankcase to cool. Insert the crankshaft through the rear bearing opening and guide the key slotted end through the front bearing inner race. Position the crankcase so that it is completely supported on the ball bearing inner race. Press the crank- shaft into place until the cheek of the shaft contacts the bearing inner race.

caution.para: The crankcase must be entirely supported by the bearing inner race or the bearing may be damaged.

step1.para: If no means of heating the crankcase is available, press the crankshaft front bearing into the crankcase recess ( Figure 30). Press only on the bearing outer race. Be sure that the bearing is seated squarely against the bottom of the case.

figure.caption: Figure 30. Pressing Crankshaft Front Bearing Into Crankcase Recess

step1.para: Support the front bearing inner race with pieces of tubing in an arbor press ( Figure 31). Place a piece of tubing on the end of the crankshaft and press the shaft into the front bearing until the cheek of the shaft contacts the bearing inner race. Do not press on the rear bearing outer race.

figure.caption: Figure 31. Pressing Crankshaft Into Front Bearing

step1.para: Lubricate with the type of refrigerant oil used in the system and install a new O-ring on the crankshaft rear bearing housing. Place the rear bearing housing on the crankshaft rear bearing and tap the housing squarely onto the bearing ( Figure 32). Align the mounting screw holes and install the screws. Tighten to 9 to 17 ft-lbs. (12 to 23 N•m) in the proper sequence ( Figure 33).

figure.caption: Figure 32. Installing Crankshaft Rear Bearing Housing
Figure 33. Rear Bearing Housing Screw Tightening Sequence

step1.para: Coat the connecting rod bearing surfaces with the refrigerant oil used in the system being serviced. Reinstall the pistons in the cylinders from which they were removed. Check the match marks to make sure that piston-connecting rod assembly, connecting rod cap and the crankshaft bearing throw all match. Install the cap retaining screws and tighten to 12 to 16 ft-lbs. (16 to 22 N•m).

caution.para: At installation, the wrist pin roll pin must face towards the center of the compressor. If positioned to face outwards, the roll pin may contact the crankshaft when the piston is at the bottom of its stroke.

step1.para: Using a new gasket, dip it in the type of refrigerant oil used in the system, then install and secure the base plate to the crankcase with capscrews. Tighten to 12 to 18 ft-lbs. (16 to 24 N•m) in proper sequence ( Figure 34).

figure.caption: Figure 34. Base Plate Capscrew Tightening Sequence

note.para: Before assembly to the compressor, all gaskets must be dipped in the type of refrigerant oil used in the system. The gaskets are made of fiber-neoprene composition and wicking action will result as the oil follows the fiber. Wicking is normal and is to be expected.

step1.para: Refer to the VALVE PLATE ASSEMBLY AND SHAFT SEAL ASSEMBLY, to complete reassembly of the compressor.
